qas.question: The frequent availability of what substance allowed land-based steam engines to exhaust a great deal of steam?
People of what nationality invented the steam turbine?
What was an example of a type of warship that required high speed?
Other than warships, what ships typically required high speeds?
In what year was HMS Dreadnought launched?
The frequent availability of what substance allowed land-based steam engines to exhaust a great deal of battleships?
People of what nationality invented the HMS Dreadnought?
What was an example of a type of warship that required expansion engines?
What ships, other than warships, typically required expansion engines?
In what year was World War I launched?

context: Land-based steam engines could exhaust much of their steam, as <a0_0><a0_2><b5_0>feed <a0_1>water<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> was usually readily available. Prior to and during World War I, the expansion engine dominated marine applications where high vessel speed was not essential. It was however superseded by the <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b6_0>British<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> invention steam turbine where speed was required, for instance in warships, such as the <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b7_0>dreadnought battleships<b7_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, and <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b8_0>ocean liners<b8_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>. HMS Dreadnought of <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><b9_0>1905<b9_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/> was the first major warship to replace the proven technology of the reciprocating engine with the then-novel steam turbine.[citation needed]
